Topic.Title: Market not expecting much from tomorrow's presentation...

Message.Msg: I am probably in the minority among longs about this. I doubt there will be hard financial numbers revealed at the GTC - perhaps some conceptual outlook for 2013 results in the context of myriad new products. Market could still react positively to news re. Project Denver update with concrete timetable and meaningful details; new partnership with tech heavy weights; pricing information on prospective new products. I really don't think the GTC will be considered an appropriate time/place to announce new design wins. However, I would be happy if I am wrong.

Message.Title: Electronic Arts Ousts CEO as New Game Consoles Await
Message.Msg: "John Riccitiello was ousted as chief executive officer of video-game maker Electronic Arts Inc. (EA), a casualty of shrinking sales as the industry gears up for new consoles no one is sure shoppers want. Chairman Larry Probst, 63, who ran Electronic Arts until 2007, becomes executive chairman and will lead management as the board seeks a new CEO, according to a statement yesterday. The Redwood City, California-based company, the second-largest U.S. game publisher, rose as much as 7.9 percent after saying Riccitiello, 53, will leave at the end of this month. “He lasted a pretty long time given that the company hasn’t really performed that well,” said Edward Woo, an analyst at Ascendiant Capital Markets in Irvine, California. “The fact that their stock is up on the news goes to show investors weren’t that big a fan.” Sales have fallen in three of the past four quarters Bloomberg data show, and the company said yesterday that fourth- quarter results will miss its previous forecast, which had already been lowered in January. “My decision to leave EA is really all about my accountability for the shortcomings in our financial results this year,” Riccitiello said in a blog posting. Riccitiello, a former Sara Lee Corp. executive, compiled a mixed record at Electronic Arts, nurturing winning franchises like “FIFA” soccer while commissioning expensive releases such as the multiplayer “Star Wars” and “Medal of Honor” that failed to meet expectations. The company flubbed the latest version of its popular “SimCity,” which some users couldn’t play because Electronic Arts’ computers were overwhelmed, said Woo, who rates the stock neutral. Game Shifts" _________________________________________________________________________ An example of what Pressure can do. Jen-Hsung is smart he will address the issues in time. But undeniably there is Pressure....if you think not then ask yourself why did Nvidia start a dividend and a share buy back program.

Message.Title: Off the hot press of WSJ: NVIDIA's roadmap includes cloud server system
Message.Msg: By DON CLARK SAN JOSE, Calif.—Nvidia Corp. NVDA said it will introduce what it called its first complete system of hardware and software, an offering designed to move graphics-heavy computing chores from desktop systems to the cloud. The Silicon Valley company calls the forthcoming product the Grid visual computing "appliance," a server-style device that is packed with Nvidia graphics chips and runs software that normally requires expensive workstations that typically reside in company offices. Nvidia said the approach means that users of, say, Apple Inc.'s AAPL Mac laptops or inexpensive tablets running Google Inc.'s GOOG Android software can remotely tap into programs that now only run on PCs running Microsoft Corp.'s MSFT Windows operating system. "They can all effectively have a powerful workstation on their desk," said Jen-Hsun Huang, Nvidia's chief executive, during the company's annual technology conference here. Besides creating animation or other graphics content, the technology can also be used to show them off, Nvidia said. Audi AG, NSU.XE -1.71% for example, demonstrated how a tablet user could view and manipulate realistic three-dimensional renderings of new cars, inside and out. Nvidia said the Grid system would be available in May from authorized dealers, starting at $24,900 for the hardware, plus an annual software license of $2,400. The company also provided new details of its chip roadmap. For its graphics chips, Mr. Huang described a future chip—code-named Volta—that will exploit a new technology for stacking memory chips to save space in a system and move data more quickly back and forth. For its Tegra mobile chip line, Nvidia described three future chips. One, dubbed Logan, will be the first to incorporate an Nvidia technology called CUDA that has been used for non-graphics chores in massive supercomputers and other systems, Mr. Huang said. Another chip coming later, called Parker, will be the first to take advantage of transistors using a new three-dimensional design known as FinFETs. Intel Corp. INTC -0.80% is the only company delivering such transistors today, but chip manufacturing services such as Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., 2330.TW -0.50% Samsung Electronics Co. 005930.SE +2.08% and Globalfoundries Inc. have vowed to follow suit. A third Tegra model, dubbed Kayla, is designed to draw extremely little power and combine graphics with an extremely powerful processor based on technology licensed by ARM Holdings ARM.LN -2.61% PLC, Mr. Huang said.

Message.Title: CNET comments on the 2 next-gen Tegra SoCs: Logan and Parker
Message.Msg: ""Logan will incorporate Nvidia's Kepler GPU, which currently is dominating the discrete graphics market. It also will include CUDA, Nvidia's programming model for GPUs that allows users to do many tasks at once. Parker, meanwhile, will be Nvidia's first processor from its Project Denver push. That includes full 64-bit capabilities, making it more attractive for use as the brains in one's computer or in a server or supercomputer. Nvidia first started talking about Project Denver during the Consumer Electronics Show in 2011, but it hadn't provided many updates since that time. Parker also will incorporate a Maxwell GPU, Nvidia's next-generation architecture. "In five years time, we'll increase Tegra by 100 times," Huang said. "Moore's Law would suggest an eightfold increase." Nvidia today is hosting its GPU Technology developers conference. Traditionally known for making graphics processing units found in computers and game consoles, Nvidia has been counting on its Tegra mobile chips to help offset weakness in its core PC market. So far, it hasn't been enough. Its presence in smartphones has been minimal, and the bulk of Tegra sales are for a couple of tablets, the Google Nexus 7 and the Microsoft Surface. In addition, Nvidia now is facing more competition in the tablet market." cnetDOTcom/8301-1035_3-57574952-94/nvidia-ceo-unveils-next-two-gens-of-tegra-dubbed-logan-parker/

Topic.Title: Nvidia lost Nexus 7

Message.Msg: Roundhouse, I certainly echo your thoughts. I think JH deliver a rich plate of all kinds of goodies, including: --New GPU technological advancements inside NV --Validation of existing roadmaps and extension into new ones with features clearly spelled out, and approximate timetables given --Development of new products (VCA etc) to capture the sea migration to cloud, especially in the enterprise sector. By doing so, NV greatly leverages technologies that are part of its core competences. --Development of new SW tools - Kayla being the next gen CUDA --Acceleration of apps based on GPU computing; luminary examples too numerous and exciting to cite --Denver update for the first time (officially) since 209/2010 (?); the implication that performance acceleration by Tegra family of SoCs would exceed what Moore's law would predict for x-86 chips is truly exciting By staying strictly on the technical side, NVIDIA would be able to continually attract high-power participants for this meeting, instead of turning it into a financial briefing session which would've turned off many scientists, engineers and collaborators. -

Message.Msg: "Qualcomm to Replace NVIDIA for Google's Next-Gen Nexus 7" "Qualcomm (NASDAQ: QCOM ) could be on the cusp of securing an order for several million additional processors. This is surprising news considering the fanfare behind the Tegra 3 in 2012 and the anticipation for its follow-up, the Tegra 4" Source: Nasdaq Did Nvidia LET QCOM Take their Google Nexus Job? lol imho

Topic.Title: Tegra 5 in 2013?

Message.Msg: What concerns me is the marketability for such a chip. By all accounts, Tegra 4 is the best SoC on the market, as far as next gen chips. By independent benchmarks, it will outperform all competitors, to include QCOMs Snapdragon series. But, as evidenced by Google's decision to use QCOM for the Nexus 7, Tegra 4 isn't being awarded many design wins, despite the independently verified performance advantages. Honestly, I'm thinking Tegra 4 is looking like a bust. I love the capabilities of the chip, but for whatever reason, manufacturers aren't. So, I'm naturally questioning the marketability of another chip, with even greater peformance ability, if there is no market for it, or demand on the part of manufacturers. To be honest, at this point, I'm more excited for T4i's ability to take marketshare away in smartphones, as well as NVDA's plans for new GPUs and GRID capabilities. I don't work in a graphics intense field, but after watching the presentation today, I couldn't help but be impressed with the new processing capabilities that NVDA will be offering companies in the near future. I was expecially blown away with the instantaneous rendering of the visual effects work, doing in 1 second what currently takes over three hours to do. I'm still long on the company with a substantial position, but I find myself slowly putting more faith into the transformation of their GPU abilitiy in relation to business efficiency more than I do their abilities in SoC and mobile. I sincerely hope they prove me wrong.

Message.Title: Well, I was wrong. The volume never really came in.
Message.Msg: It's quite surprising to me that after an initial surge in volume and one brief move higher during the presentation (back over 12.50), that there wasn't more volume at the end of the day. The presentation was terrific, and perhaps many of the PMs were too busy watching their entire positions to watch either part of this during market hours, but how anyone who DID see it could not be VERY impressed (esp. with the VCA) is beyond me. Then his explanation of the company's game plan for the business, and why they're investing as they are due to a "once in a lifetime opportunity, which is NOW or NEVER") was equally compelling to me. I'm sure some were hoping to hear about the launch date and pricing of Shield, but I think they're holding that back until PAX East, this weekend. So, today wasn't the day, and I'm sure Mslans and a few others will continue to think nothing will move this stock, but it will happen, and when it does it will come out of nowhere and you'll have missed the first 10-20%, in a matter of days or a week or two, if you leave now. As always, we'll know in the fullness of time. M

Message.Title: Anandtech has additional info on Logan/Parker. Logan sampling in 2013, production in early 2014
Message.Msg: First up is Logan, which will be NVIDIA's first SoC with CUDA inside, specifically courtesy a Kepler architecture GPU capable of CUDA 5.0 and OpenGL 4.3. There's no details on the CPU side of things, but we're told to expect Logan demos (and samples) inside 2013 and production inside devices early 2014. After Logan is Parker, which NVIDIA shared will contain the codename Denver CPU NVIDIA is working on, with 64 bit capabilities and codename Maxwell GPU. Parker will also be built using 3D FinFET transistors, likely from TSMC. We're going to see what more we can find out about Logan and Parker later today. In addition NVIDIA showed off a new product named Kayla which is a small, mITX-like board running a Tegra 3 SoC and unnamed new low power Kepler family GPU. anandtechDOTcom/show/6845/nvidia-updates-tegra-roadmap-details-at-gtc-logan-and-parker-detailed

Message.Title: A Wholesale Change For Nvidia --- A Server Co. Now?
Message.Msg: The introduction of Nvidia Grid with the largest Server Companies and Virtualization cos. in the world starting this quarter is a very good thing for Nvidia. For small and medium businesses Nvidia VCA(instead of individual workstations) is also a good thing. Market can really be much larger than Tegra this year. Let's see how they do on execution, but the concept is good. Just one note: 1000 Nvidia VCA's brings in as much revenue as 2M Tegras or 10 million cheap radios. Yearly site license revenue for the software is a good thing too.l Looks like a drop down a couple of notches in the importance of mobile computing to Nvidia for 3 months or so. Of course you go with what you got right now. No financials....Big Disappointment....Analyst's questions still show much confusion about Nvidia. WS financial firms will probably have to reassign some server co. analysts to help out the semi analysts. Even Jensen noticed Sammie is introducing Galaxy S4 with a game pad controller attachment.

Until then, I still think we're pretty much sitting on dead money. Now I don't mind, as I am investing in the long term picture here, but I can see why others would be frustrated.

Message.Title: "Nvidia may lose almost eight million processor shipments in 2013"
Message.Msg: " Second-generation Nexus 7 to use Qualcomm processor Monica Chen, Taipei; Joseph Tsai, DIGITIMES [Monday 18 March 2013] Google's and Asustek Computer's co-branded second-generation Nexus 7 tablet reportedly has adopted a solution from Qualcomm instead of Nvidia, which was the processor supplier of the first-generation Nexus 7, according to sources from the upstream supply chain. The second-generation Nexus 7 is expected to launch in May and without the orders, Nvidia may lose almost eight million processor shipments in 2013, the sources noted. Nvidia shipped over 10 million Tegra 3s for tablets in 2012 with six million units supplied to Google for the first-generation Nexus 7. The rest of the volume was shipped to players such as Lenovo, Acer and China's white-box players, the sources said. The sources believe pricing is not the reason Asustek turned to place orders to Qualcomm as Nvidia's and Qualcomm's chips have a similar price level and is likely because of the chips' communication chip integration process. Although Nvidia has released the Tegra 4i with an integrated 4G LTE chip, the processor was not able to catch up with the second-generation Nexus 7's launch schedule.: Source: Digitimes

Message.Title: FORBES: NVIDIA's Volta GPU Launches In 2016, Delivers 1TB/s Of Memory Bandwidth
Message.Msg: NVIDIA has always been a forward-thinking company, and that was never more apparent than during today’s keynote at the GPU Technology Conference in San Jose. CEO Jen-Hsun Huang was visibly anxious to unveil the company’s Volta, their upcoming GPU targeted for a 2016 release. “Volta is going to solve one of the biggest challenges facing GPUs today, which is access to memory bandwidth. We never seem to have enough!” Huang told the attendees. “This is unbelievable stuff.” Unbelievable indeed. The Volta GPU will introduce stacked DRAM (dynamic random access memory). On a technical level, this is accomplished by having multiple layers of DRAM stacked atop each other on the same silica substrate, then drilling a hole through the silicon and connecting each layer. But what does this mean in layman’s terms for graphic artists, video editors, animators and gaming enthusiasts? 1 terabyte per second of memory bandwidth. 1TB/s of memory bandwidth means you could move the contents of a jam-packed Blu-ray disc through the chip in a mere 1/50th of a second. Consider that NVIDIA’s Titan GPU — its latest high-end graphics card — can handle about 288GB/s, and you can only imagine the positive implications for a wide range of people depending on graphics processing horsepower, from game developers to graphic artists. Obviously it’s too soon to expect a price tag or firm release date, but NVIDIA’s GPU roadmap looks exciting.

Message.Title: Big Data Server........Sorter? I heard There Was A Lot O Big Data Around
Message.Msg: an Jose, California (PRWEB) March 19, 2013 SQream Technologies Ltd., the leading analytics database technology provider, and Mellanox® Technologies, a leading supplier of high-performance, end-to-end interconnect solutions for data center servers and storage systems, today announced a Big Data analytics platform that leverages the SQream’s GPU-powered Analytics Engine, Mellanox’s VSA™ Storage Accelerator software, and Mellanox’s ConnectX®-3 FDR 56Gb/s InfiniBand adapter cards with NVIDIA GPUDirect™ technology. The solution enables extreme performance gains by eliminating the need for CPU involvement when reading data from SAN appliance directly into the GPU RAM. “The SQream Analytics Engine combined with the Mellanox FDR InfiniBand and NVIDIA GPUDirect technology provides unrivaled enterprise-class Big Data analytics performance that can only be achieved by more expensive solutions,” said Ami Gal, CEO, SQream Technologies. “We have already proven extreme performance to market and now, through this collaboration with Mellanox, we are providing customers with even much higher performance gains.” SQream Analytics Engine enables business analysts to harness the power of the GPU-powered database via SQL and conduct investigative and predictive analytics. The combined solution provides and added boost in the SQream's performance and delivers a much higher cost effectiveness compared to other well-known analytic databases. “Mellanox is pleased to bring our VSA and ConnectX-3 solutions to the SQream Analytics Engine,” said Gilad Shainer, vice president of marketing development at Mellanox Technologies. “Customers who deploy our highly acclaimed products with SQream’s database are provided with a compelling enterprise solution that is powerful, cost-effective and easy to use and deploy
